title: 113_s2417
content: The Act titled "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" imposes a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. The Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014 imposes a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. Section 207(e)(1) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to restrict former Senators, Members of the House of Representatives, or elected officers from influencing Congress on behalf of others after leaving office. The Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014 imposes a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. Section 207(e)(1) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to restrict former Senators, Members of the House of Representatives, or elected officers from influencing Congress on behalf of others after leaving office. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to Section 207(e)(2) of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 3 of the Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014 extends the restriction on Congressional staff from lobbying from 1 year to 6 years. SEC. 4 focuses on improving the reporting of lobbyists' activities. Section 6 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to create a joint lobbyist disclosure Internet database called lobbyists.gov. The database will be maintained by the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives with a goal of simplicity in usage. $100,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2015 to carry out this subsection. Any person who is a registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal cannot be hired by a Member or committee of Congress within 6 years of leaving their position if they had substantial lobbying contact. A waiver can be granted by the Committee on Ethics or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct based on a compelling national need. When considering hiring a person who has had substantial lobbying contact, Congress must assess if the contacts were related to legislative business, earmarks, or fundraising activities. Simple social interactions do not count as substantial lobbying contacts. SEC. 6A. REPORTING BY SUBSTANTIAL LOBBYING ENTITIES. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to include reporting requirements for substantial lobbying entities. Substantial lobbying entities must annually report to the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the United States Senate any employees, contractors, or consultants who are former members of Congress or congressional staff meeting specific criteria. The filing required by this section for substantial lobbying entities must include a brief job description of former members of Congress or congressional staff meeting specific criteria, along with an explanation of their work experience. The filing for substantial lobbying entities must include job descriptions of former members of Congress or congressional staff meeting specific criteria, along with an explanation of their work experience. The Joint Web site lobbyists.gov will have a database for 'Substantial Lobbying Entities' and provide copies of filings to law enforcement for oversight. The District of Columbia United States Attorney receives filings from substantial lobbying entities to determine if they are accurately reporting federal lobbying activities. A substantial lobbying entity is defined as an incorporated entity with more than 3 federally registered lobbyists. SEC. 7 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to increase penalties from $200,000 to $500,000.
